conclusion: Analyze forces on conductor rod using energy conservation and motion under magnetic field.
Smooth rail inclined at angle θ with conductor rod ab perpendicular to rail, magnetic field B downward, resistor R at lower end.
Gravity force mg sin θ causes rod to accelerate downward.
Rod experiences magnetic force F_m = BvL perpendicular to motion.
Magnetic force opposes rod's motion, slowing it down.
At maximum speed, magnetic force equals gravity force, F_m = mg sin θ.
Solve for velocity at maximum speed: v = mg sin θ / BL.
Kinetic energy at maximum speed: 1/2 mv^2 = 1/2 m(mg sin θ / BL)^2.
Potential energy at top of incline: mgh = mgL sin θ.
Energy conservation: mgL sin θ = 1/2 m(mg sin θ / BL)^2 + 1/2 m(mg sin θ / BL)^2.
Magnetic potential energy: 1/2 m(mg sin θ / BL)^2.
Time t using equation of motion: v = d/t, where d is distance traveled.
Substitute velocity expression: mg sin θ / BL = x/t.
Solve for time t: t = xBL / mg sin θ.
Time t for conductor rod to slide down is xBL / mg sin θ.
